well-drained gravel ridge tops cliffs dry soil banks dry tundra
bio:treatment.discussion: Plants of subsp. arenosa from Alaska and Yukon tend to be larger, with more open inflorescences and more distinctly petiolulate central leaflets, than plants in north-central Canada. Some collections from the range of Potentilla furcata (sect. Rubricaules) have red glands in the inflorescence, suggesting introgression between P. arenosa and P. furcata. Reported occurrences in Alberta and Saskatchewan (and the upper altitudinal limit given here) might actually be P. hookeriana as now circumscribed.
